headline: Software Architect at Salesforce
summary:
Accomplished, focused, and diligent Senior Software Development Engineer who is passionate about software craftsmanship and system architecture. Scrupulous in the practice of pragmatic and agile development methods. Looking to contribute to and lead teams of smart people working on large-scale, distributed applications and using forward-focused technologies.
Also, blog and book author, speaker at regional and international conferences and local user groups, and mentor of junior software developers.

NOTE: Do *not* contact me about positions that would require me to relocate / move away from the Denver, CO area.

Specialties: - Ruby/RoR, Python, Scala, Clojure, Java, Objective-C, Golang, PHP, Perl/Mason,  C/C++
- Distributed Systems, Design Patterns
- Linux, Mac OS X, Windows

experiences.title: Software Architect
experiences.description: Planning, designing, and leading implementation projects for Salesforce's Trailblazers on the Trailhead Engineer team

experiences.title: Principal Member Of Technical Staff
experiences.description: Developing robust services, APIs and SOA tooling on the Trailhead Engineer team

experiences.title: Sr. Software Engineer
experiences.description:
Member of the Imagery Processing team in Uber's Advanced Technologies, Engineering group. I am helping to design, and build an end-to-end system to manage, track, analyze, and process the data used to improve the maps from around the world.
* Processing petabytes of imagery data to prepare them for feature extraction & ML algorithms
* Distributed computing in Hadoop/HDFS, Spark, and Cassandra environment
* Designing and implementing polyglot systems in Python, Scala, Java, Node.js and Golang

experiences.title: Author and Independent Software Consultant
experiences.description:
* Author of the upcoming "Microservices From Day One" book, published by Apress Media. 
* Providing independent software consulting services regarding systems architecture, design, development and operational support.
* Specialization in helping clients with adopting Microservices as an architectural style
* Training on "How To Get Started" and Best Practices
* Technical Due Diligence support
* Sofware Development services (either embedded in an existing engineering team or acting as the early-stage implementor and mentor for newly on-boarded engineers)
* Consulting as a Senior Team Lead or Principal Engineer

	Object-oriented analysis, design, and implementation in C/C++ of 2 subsystems (Instrument Interface, Guiding Control)

	Development Team Leader, Software Designer (Java Servlet / JSP, Microsoft ASP), Technical Consultant (in Professional Services organization); Deployment Manager and Researcher (in R&D department).

experiences.description: 	 Member of the Core Services Team, designing, and continually improving, feature capabilities, scalability and performance of LivingSocial's technology platform. Applying a wide range of technologies on a daily basis (Ruby / Rails, Clojure / Datomic, Scala, JavaScript, iOS).

accomplishment_projects.title: Speaker / Workshop trainer at AbrilPro Ruby (Brazil) & Rocky Mountain Ruby (Colorado) 2014
accomplishment_projects.description:
Adopting SOA from Day One:
In this workshop, we explained what a Service-Oriented Architecture is, its advantages, and the reasons why developers should think about it when starting an application.

volunteer_work.title: Guide for opportunity scholar
volunteer_work.description:
A Rocky Mountain Ruby 2016 Guide helps to bring a new community member into the Ruby community. 
Guides volunteer to partner up with this year's Opportunity Scholars. Opportunity Scholars are people who are new to the Ruby community or language, or may be new to programming altogether, and they're ready to have their first Rocky Mountain Ruby experience. They can tell amazing stories of their path to Rocky Mountain Ruby, and they are going to be wonderful additions to our community. A guide's job is to help us welcome them and make them feel at home!

While there is certainly an intangible component of what makes a great Guide, there are also a few things that we're looking for specifically:

* Guides should be comfortable being available as a friendly face for their Scholars throughout the whole conference. 
* Guides should be able to recommend great talks for Scholars to attend after hearing about their interests, current skill levels, and experiences.
* Guides should be comfortable making introductions between Scholars and established developers, especially ones that might be influential in  the Scholars' areas of interest.
* Guides should be able to give feedback on breaking into the Ruby world, especially for Scholars looking for their first Ruby or Rails gig!
* Guides should be great community ambassadors!
